text:
<@U01UYA5NHD2>
I'm measured on increased pageviews for the pages I work on.

Image optimization: on a case-by-case basis. If an image looks outdated, or is of bad quality, I'll replace it. Same is it hasn't been optimized for size/weight.

Adding new images: also just based on the content of the article and a feeling of where an image could improve clarity or break up large chunks of text.

I always do an audit of the existing content before I start working on something and I always check if they're already ranking for a keyword if I choose to optimize an article for another keyword than the one that was initially the target keyword.

Not sure what you mean by "Are you literally embedded in a content team?" I'm a freelancer and when I do content optimization, it's me and my assistant doing the content optimization. If the client has a larger content team or in-house content marketers, we'll set up a system to make sure they don't target keywords with new articles that I might optimize for but other than that, I pretty much have my own workflow.

How I price this: as a monthly retainer. The price depends on how much content the client wants to have optimized every month.

text:
*Is it bad to have 1 blog rank for 1k+ keywords?*
We have a blog that’s kind of a catch all for a ton of keywords. That’s served us well with bringing our site traffic, but it doesn’t service the intent of all these keywords (I can tell because it consistently ranks between 10-50 for these KWs). So…
1. Should I create new content that better services the intent of those keywords and link to that new content from the OG blog?
2. Should I re-optimize the (again and again) to make sure it maintains it’s ranking for all those KWs?
3. Should I hone in on only the highest value keywords and optimize for that (accepting that I’ll lose other keywords as a result)?
Sincerely,
Kind of confused rookie marketer looking for content pro insight :sweat_smile:

elements.text: Is it bad to have 1 blog rank for 1k+ keywords?

We have a blog that’s kind of a catch all for a ton of keywords. That’s served us well with bringing our site traffic, but it doesn’t service the intent of all these keywords (I can tell because it consistently ranks between 10-50 for these KWs). So…
Should I create new content that better services the intent of those keywords and link to that new content from the OG blog?
Should I re-optimize the (again and again) to make sure it maintains it’s ranking for all those KWs?
Should I hone in on only the highest value keywords and optimize for that (accepting that I’ll lose other keywords as a result)?

Sincerely,
Kind of confused rookie marketer looking for content pro insight

text:
First - I would think about whether the true intent of those KWs maps to your product solution areas/user needs or reaches your target market. If not, I think it’s worth reflecting on why you’re ranking for KWs that don’t serve your business in the first place.

If they do help your business, I would definitely optimize to meet search intent. You’re only creating bounce/bad brand impression if you rank for a KW but don’t match the search intent. I would do that prioritizing based on value.

Imo, it’s also totally okay to remove content that doesn’t serve your business or reader and have your blog be more laser focused on content that aligns with business results and providing a stellar content/reader experience.

But if you choose to keep it, try to think about a micro-conversion you could drive (email collection, for example) so they’re driving more than eyeballs, which at the end of the day is just a vanity metric.

Hope this helps somewhat!!

text:
While this type of content isn't necessarily "black hat", it will dilute your traffic and, as you said, not be a great match for searcher intent or the purpose of the page.

I'd say your first option is probably your best, but eventually, you may want to consider creating separate, optimized pieces for each keyword group and then using a permanent redirect or canonical tag from the original page once you're done.

That being said, I would still scale down your keywords to the ones that are the most relevant to your site and users. While you may lose some traffic initially, you'll benefit from higher-quality traffic over time, and may even gain a better position in SERPs.

Feel free to DM me if you'd like to discuss!

text:
This is normal. Do 1. But make it a considered hub and spoke topic cluster so you get the linking right and make sure your mega blog links out to all the spoke ones. You may even need to fragment the mega blog even further into 2/3 that have a cluster around them. Just work on 
1) proximity to your offer
2) kw volume + difficulty
3) how well you're currently ranking. 
Ranking 15 onwards is meaningless - those kw  all should probably be serviced by different content
